intro: Pseudogynoxys telembina, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, bright orange to red composite flowers. The plant typically grows as an annual or biennial herb, reaching heights of up to 2 meters, with hairy stems and alternate leaves. Its flowers are composed of ray florets and disc florets, and it is often cultivated for its ornamental value. Pseudogynoxys telembina is also known for its ability to thrive in poor soils and full sun conditions.
